topic.name: Torah (The Pentateuch)
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Torah (The Pentateuch) in Bible & Theology

objectives.objective_text: Identify Genesis as the book of 'Beginnings'.
Identify Numbers as the book where they counted the people.
Name the 12 spies who went into the land.
Identify Deuteronomy as Moses' last speech.
Name the command to love God with all our heart.
Identify Exodus as the book about leaving Egypt.
Name Moses as the leader God chose.
Name the first man and woman made by God.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Identify rules (Law) and good news (Gospel).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Name Jesus as the one who kept the rules for us.
Identify Leviticus as a book about holiness.
Name the priests as helpers in God's house.
Recall that the people complained a lot in the desert.
Observe the cloud that led them by day.
Recall that obedience brings blessings.
Observe that God wants us to remember His laws.
Recall the crossing of the Red Sea.
Observe the Ten Commandments as God's rules.
Recall the story of Noah's Ark.
Observe that God made everything good.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Recall that we cannot keep all the rules perfectly.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Observe that God forgives us when we fail.
Recall that God wants His people to be clean.
Observe that sin is serious.
Categorize Genesis as the foundation for the rest of the Bible.
Summarize the rebellion at Kadesh Barnea.
Explain why they wandered for 40 years (one year for each day spied).
Explain the transition from the old generation to the new generation.
Perform research on the geography of the wilderness journey.
Summarize the 'Shema' (Hear, O Israel...).
Explain that Deuteronomy means 'Second Law'.
Explain the significance of Moses' death on Mt. Nebo.
Defend the unity of the Law.
Produce an essay on how Deuteronomy serves as the theological center of the OT.
Summarize the ten plagues and the Passover.
Explain the meaning of 'Exodus' (road out/departure).
Explain the purpose of the Tabernacle dwelling.
Defend the historicity of the event against minimalist claims.
Produce an essay on Exodus as the paradigm for salvation in the Bible.
Summarize the lives of the four Patriarchs (Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Joseph).
Explain the two main sections: Primeval History (1-11) and Patriarchal History (12-50).
Perform research on the cultural background of patriarchal customs.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Summarize how the Law shows us our sin.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Explain how the sacrifices show us God's grace.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Explain how grace is present even in the Old Testament.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Defend the continuity of salvation by grace through faith in both Testaments.
Summarize the five main offerings (Burnt, Grain, Peace, Sin, Guilt).
Explain what 'Holy' means (set apart/perfect).
Categorize the feasts of Israel found in Leviticus 23.
Explain the role of the Scapegoat.
Defend the necessity of blood sacrifice.
Compare the faith of Joshua and Caleb with the fear of the others.
Apply the story of the Bronze Serpent.
Analyze the layout of the camp with the Tabernacle in the center.
Interpret the story of Balaam and his donkey.
Connect the grumbling of Israel to the spiritual danger of discontent.
Compare the blessings for obeying and the curses for disobeying.
Apply the command to teach God's word to children.
Analyze the structure of the book as a Suzerain-Vassal treaty.
Interpret the requirement for the future King.
Connect Deuteronomy to Jesus' temptation (He quoted it 3 times).
Compare the slavery in Egypt to freedom in the wilderness.
Apply the lesson that God rescues His people.
Analyze the structure: Deliverance (1-18), Covenant (19-24), Tabernacle (25-40).
Interpret the significance of the Divine Name (Yahweh/I AM).
Connect the Passover Lamb to Christ.
Compare the creation account with the fall of man.
Analyze the structure of the 'Toledot' (generations) throughout the book.
Interpret the significance of the Abrahamic Covenant for world history.
Connect the 'seed of the woman' promise to the rest of the book.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Compare trying to be good with trusting in God.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Apply the idea that the Law is a guide for how to live, not how to be saved.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the Three Uses of the Law (Mirror, Restraint, Guide).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Interpret Paul's statement that the Law is a 'tutor' to lead us to Christ.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Connect the failure of Israel to keep the Law with the need for a New Covenant.
Compare clean and unclean animals.
Analyze the Day of Atonement ceremony (Leviticus 16).
Interpret the call to 'Be holy, for I am holy.'
Connect the dietary laws to the idea of separation from the nations.
Explain the theology of Election in the choice of Jacob over Esau.
Evaluate the character flaws of Moses that kept him from the Promised Land.
Evaluate the 'Deuteronomic History' hypothesis.
Evaluate the date of the Exodus (Early vs. Late date).
Evaluate the literary framework view of Genesis 1 versus literal creationism.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the error of legalism vs. antinomianism.
Evaluate the relevance of the Holiness Code for New Testament believers.
Construct a timeline of the wilderness wanderings.
Synthesize the typology of the wilderness as the Christian life.
Construct a map of the possible routes of the Exodus.
Construct a defense of Mosaic authorship against the Documentary Hypothesis.
Synthesize the theme of God's sovereignty in the Joseph narrative.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the Torah as a witness to Christ.
Synthesize the book of Leviticus with the book of Hebrews.
Construct a theology of the 'heart' in Deuteronomy.
Construct a theology of substitutionary atonement based on Leviticus.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Construct a clear distinction between Law and Gospel hermeneutics.
